content.description: Climb up to the obvious layback flake through the overhanging section left of Brainstorm. At its top go up and right (don't eject) then back left and up to anchor on Brainstorm. 30m rap.
content.protection: Draws, maybe a couple of cams.

content.description:
P1. 11c. 30m. Find a flake to get through the steep bit right of Brainstorm, go up the clean slab leftwards then through the double roofs to a stance.

P2. 10b. 33m. Up the face past 6 bolts to a crack and the anchor.

Honestly, we only climbed a portion of the route after getting off the Beckey route.

The pitches seem to be:

P1 - moderate approach pitch angling slightly up and left towards the slab left of large roof, 5.7?

P2 - 7

P3 - 9, bolt + gear

P4 - tricky 5.10 slab, this is the pitch we climbed

P5 - topo indicates this is the crux pitch, did not climb

P6 - ? the buttress eases back, and like the Beckey, the rating probably eases a bit
content.protection: crux pitches are bolted, spaced but adequate. Standard Portal rack up to 3.5" or so?

content.location: The line between Infallible and Big Chief No Show.

content.description:
P1. 11c. 30m. Up past 7 bolts through the Brainstorm traverse.

P2. 11c. 35m. Move right and up past a bunch of bolts. Crux up high.

P1. Face climbing to a thin right facing corner. Crux getting started in the corner.

P2. Nice face. Much easier. Rap
content.protection: Draws. A couple of small pieces can be used up in the corner but they're not essential.
content.location: First line left of Crystal Meth.

content.description:
This left facing dihedral leads to the flake belay on the Beckey. We did an incorrect direct direct start up a very grainy dihedral, which was fine. The actual start is much farther right.

A seam angles left up a golden stained slab under a roof. This deposits you a the base of a large left facing dihedral. Move left at the top of the dihedral, around the corner to the flakes atop Beckey P1.
content.protection: Standard rack sufficed. Additionally, a BD #4 was key as were some small cams.
content.location: A fair bit right of the normal start up the drainage between El Segundo and Premier buttresses.

climbs.name: Beckey Route
climbs.fa: Fred Beckey and Mike Heath, March 1971, FFA Dean Hobbs, Will Crljenko, February 1977

content.description: P-1 rope stretcher. Start at a dirty dihedral which gains a ledge. Negotiate some brush then head up a right-leaning layback/offwidth, over a small roof (pretty stiff for .7) and to a slung tree belay stance, flake for anchor. P-2 Climb up and right to an arete with nice jams and gear to a wild roof move (lieback) and another 30 or so feet to a gear belay in the vertical crack up and slightly right (.75-1" cams)... do not belay from flake lower down or get suckered into going out left, the line goes straight up. P-3 Crack comes and go and with it a little run-out. Fun, techy climbing. A welcome fixed piton and more moves leads to a bolted belay out LEFT. P-4 Follow fins straight up. Bolts are hard to see looking up from the belay but they're there. (For some reason, someone put a bolt right where there's some good gear. Nice 3/4 placement) Follow up (more bolts?) to a belay at the bottom of a large crack (2-3" pieces). Fourth class leads to the summit.
content.location: Getting down is fine, but do it in the light. Your goal, once getting down sandy ledges and brushy slopes is to aim for a notch to the South. (Think Mountaineers route on Whitney but in reverse) Follow this along the base of the El Segundo Butt and back to your packs.
